awd_titl_txt: CC-NIE Integration: OneOklahoma Friction Free Network
awd_abstract_narration:
The OneOklahoma Friction Free Network (OFFN) is a collaboration among four Oklahoma institutions that have significant High Performance Computing resources available for academic research: the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma State University, the Tandy Supercomputing Center of the Oklahoma Innovation Institute, and Langston University, Oklahoma's only Historically Black University, along with OneNet, Oklahoma's education, research and government information and telecommunications network.

Triggered by research needs in high energy physics, numerical weather prediction, bioinformatics and weather radar, but available for researchers across all Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines statewide, OFFN serves as a crucial component of the OneOklahoma Cyberinfrastructure Initiative (OneOCII), which provides resources and services to researchers and educators across the state, and which has so far has served almost 100 institutions and organizations, approximately half of them academic.

The project addresses key national Cyberinfrastructure priorities, specifically deployment of friction free networking and software defined networking capabilities. Objectives include:

1. Deploy and maintain, at the four institutions, a research-only network consisting of institutional last mile components that are independent of enterprise networks, with its internal hub collocated with OneNet.

2. Apply Software Defined Networking across OFFN, facilitating end-to-end management, by researchers, of high bandwidth/high performance data flows through a distributed hierarchy of open standards tools, giving researchers a new layer of transparency into network transport.

3. Provide these capabilities -- OFFN's in particular and OneOCII's in general -- to all relevant researchers and educators statewide, and facilitate their use.

por.por_cntn:
(1) Intellectual Merit

An Advanced Cyberinfrastructure Research & Education Facilitator (ACI-REF) position was funded at the University of Oklahoma (OU), specifically a Campus Cyberinfrastructure (CI) Engineer, to implement the OneOklahoma Friction Free Network (OFFN), a friction free and Software Defined Network not just at OU but shared with and located at Oklahoma State University, Langston University (Oklahoma's only Historically Black College/University), the Oklahoma Innovation Institute (a nonprofit in Tulsa), the University of Tulsa, and the University of Central Oklahoma.

(2) Broader Impact

The ACI-REF Virtual Residency Program was implemented, teaching pre-service and in-service research computing professionals how to provide, or better provide, CI facilitation and CI engineering services.

The impact went far beyond the originally proposed three dozen or so institutions; the final tally was actually over 300 people from 181 institutions in 49 US states and 2 US territories, plus 5 other countries. Over the 3 years the grant was active, the team conducted 3 weeklong intensive "boot camp" workshops, and helped a statewide university system (in a much larger state) to conduct a mini-workshop of their own.

In addition, as an offshoot of (2), this project's Principal Investigator established a new activity, not in the original proposal, to teach CI facilitators how to write grant proposals, by writing a grant proposal together, on the understanding that the best mechanism for learning how to write grant proposals is to participate in writing a grant proposal. This activity has had 62 participants from over 50 institutions, and is poised to submit a major grant proposal in early 2018.

Thus, a project intended to have its greatest impact at the home institution is proving to have even greater impact nationally and internationally, helping to shape the Cyberinfrastructure workforce for years to come.


Last Modified: 12/29/2017
Modified by: Henry J Neeman

Addendum # 1

The intellectual merit of this project focused on deploying the OneOklahoma Friction Free Network (OFFN) across six institutions in Oklahoma: originally the University of Oklahoma (OU), Oklahoma State University (OSU), Langston University (LU, Oklahoma's only Historically Black College/University, masters-granting), the Oklahoma Innovation Institute (a nonprofit in Tulsa), and later the University of Tulsa (TU) and the University of Central Oklahoma (UCO, masters-granting). All of the OFFN institutions were targeted for 10 Gbps Ethernet (10GE) upgrades, but because of investments by OneNet, Oklahoma's research, education and government network, OFFN was able to deploy 100GE connectivity to OU's main (Norman) campus and OSU's main (Stillwater) campus. Thus, this project has been able to far exceed its originally proposed scale and scope, with a 50% increase in the number of participating institutions, and a 1000% increase in bandwidth to Oklahoma's comprehensive public PhD-granting universities. The broader impacts of this project are substantial: because of Oklahoma's unique approach to its first Campus Cyberinfrastructure award, the OFFN team was able to assist four additional non-PhD-granting institutions -- Northeastern State University (Native American Serving Non-tribal Institution), Southeastern Oklahoma State University (NASNI), Southwestern Oklahoma State University and Rogers State University -- in submitting an NSF Campus Cyberinfrastructure proposal to join OFFN, and this proposal was successfully funded, so OFFN will ultimate grow to 10 institutions, 2500% as many as originally envisioned, and will reach a total of 3 Minority Serving Institutions and 5 non-PhD-granting universities.


Added: 01/29/2018
Submitted by: Henry J Neeman
